<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage168"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
<A HREF="#O15894EXV3_HTM_TOCPAGE">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT">
<A NAME="O15894EXV3_HTM_101">
</A>
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
<I>
	OVERVIEW
</I>
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Vision
</B>
<BR>
<BR>
	Cameco will be a dominant nuclear energy company, producing uranium fuel and generating clean
	electricity.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Profile
</B>
<BR>
<BR>
	Our business is nuclear energy. We are a leading global supplier of uranium fuel and a growing
	supplier of clean electricity. We deliver shareholder value by using our unique assets, employee
	experience and industry knowledge to meet the world&#146;s rising demand for clean, safe and reliable
	energy.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	We place the safety of our workforce, the public and the environment above all else.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	We achieve sustainable growth by combining prudent financial management with personal conduct that
	reflects our values.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	The key measures of our success are a safe, healthy and rewarding workplace, a clean environment,
	supportive communities and solid financial performance&#151;all reflected in a growing return to
	shareholders.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Values
</B>
<BR>
<BR>
	We value the contribution of every employee. We seek strong relationships based on honest
	communications with employees and their families, customers, shareholders and suppliers.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	We pursue excellence in all undertakings and value people who strive to produce work of the highest
	quality. We encourage creativity, innovation and continual improvement.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	We seek to earn the respect of all people with whom we interact. We inspire trust based on honest,
	fair and ethical behaviour.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Our operations provide a safe human and physical environment. We are committed to practices that
	promote the health of employees and safeguard the environment in areas affected by the facilities
	we operate during and after their utilization.
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT">
<A NAME="O15894EXV3_HTM_102">
</A>
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
<I>
	CAMECO&#146;s BUSINESSES
</I>
</B>
<BR>
<BR>
	Cameco is involved in four business segments:
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;uranium
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;conversion services
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;nuclear electricity generation
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;gold
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	The only significant commercial use for uranium is to fuel nuclear power plants for the generation
	of electricity. In recent years, nuclear plants generated approximately 16% of the world&#146;s
	electricity.
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	3
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage169"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
<A HREF="#O15894EXV3_HTM_TOCPAGE">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	The major stages in the production of nuclear fuel are uranium exploration, mining and milling,
	refining and conversion, enrichment and fuel fabrication. Once a commercial uranium deposit is
	discovered and reserves delineated, regulatory approval to mine is sought. Following regulatory
	approval, the mine is developed, and ore is extracted and upgraded at a mill to produce uranium
	concentrate. Uranium mining companies sell uranium concentrates to nuclear electricity generating
	companies around the world on the basis of the U
<SUB>
	3
</SUB>
	O
<SUB>
	8
</SUB>
	contained in the
	concentrates. These utilities then contract with converters, enrichers and fuel fabricators to
	produce the required reactor fuel.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Cameco is the world&#146;s largest uranium producer accounting for 20% of the world&#146;s production in 2004
	and backed by more than 553&nbsp;million pounds of proven and probable reserves of uranium. We have
	controlling ownership of the world&#146;s largest high-grade reserves and low-cost operations in
	northern Saskatchewan. Cameco operates four mines in Canada and the United States, as well as two
	mines under development in Canada and Central Asia.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	The company is an integrated uranium fuel supplier with refining facilities at Blind River and
	conversion facilities at Port Hope, both located in Ontario, Canada. Uranium concentrates are
	shipped to Blind River for refining into uranium trioxide (UO
<SUB>
	3
</SUB>
	) and to Port Hope for
	conversion services. The Port Hope plant can produce 20% of the world&#146;s annual requirements of
	uranium hexafluoride (UF
<SUB>
	6
</SUB>
	) used in making fuel for light water reactors. In addition,
	Port Hope is the world&#146;s only commercial producer of natural uranium dioxide (UO
<SUB>
	2
</SUB>
	), the
	fuel used by all Canadian-designed Candu reactors. The products from these sites are used to
	produce fuel for nuclear power reactors.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Through its 31.6% interest in the Bruce Power Limited Partnership, which operates the Bruce Power
	nuclear generating station located in southern Ontario, Cameco generates clean electricity. Cameco
	is the sole fuel supplier to Bruce Power which leases eight nuclear power reactors, two of which
	have been out of service since 1995 and 1997. Bruce Power&#146;s operating plants have a combined net
	generation capacity of 4,700 megawatts (MW), which is enough to meet the residential and industrial
	needs of a city the size of Toronto, Ontario.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Cameco has a 52.7% interest in Centerra Gold Inc., which began trading on the Toronto Stock
	Exchange in June&nbsp;2004. Cameco transferred substantially all its gold assets to Centerra as part of
	the strategy to unlock the value of those assets. Centerra is a leading North American gold
	producer and the largest western-based gold producer in Central Asia. Centerra is focused on growth
	through exploration and acquisition of gold properties in Central Asia, the former Soviet Union and
	other emerging markets. Centerra operates two gold mines, located in the Kyrgyz Republic and
	Mongolia, and holds a number of exploration properties in Asia and North America.
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	4
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>

</I>
</B>
<BR>
<BR>
	Cameco&#146;s vision is to be a dominant nuclear energy company, producing uranium fuel and
	generating clean electricity. Cameco&#146;s main strategies are to:
<P>

	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>

</TD>
</TR>
<TR>

	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>

</TD>

	expand our nuclear generation capacity.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

	Our specific strategies in the uranium and conversion businesses, the company&#146;s core businesses,
	are discussed on pages 8 and 22, respectively, of this MD&#038;A.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	In pursuing further integration in nuclear fuel supply and expansion in nuclear power
	generation, our goals are to:
<P>
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">

</TD>

	provide nuclear fuel supply where possible and link to core assets and competencies,
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD COLSPAN="5">
	&nbsp;
</TD>

	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	capture the value added to uranium in each step of the fuel cycle, including the
	enormous energy value in the final production of clean electricity generation,
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD COLSPAN="5">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">

	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	strengthen Cameco&#146;s foundation for further expansion in the nuclear fuel cycle,
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD COLSPAN="5">
	&nbsp;
</TD>

</TD>

</TD>

</TD>

</TD>

<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	The key strategies are to:
<P>
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">

</TD>

</TD>

	and regulatory processes, and
</TD>

	&nbsp;
</TD>

</TD>

	leveraging fuel-supply relationships, developing expertise in new fuel requirements, and
	enhancing relationships with industry leaders in reactor technology, and, seeking active
	ownership to allow, where possible, participation in management oversight of generation
	facilities.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	In addition, Cameco seeks to increase nuclear power&#146;s contribution to global energy supply through
	two major strategies to:
<P>
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">

	5

<P>
<A NAME="eolPage171"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
<A HREF="#O15894EXV3_HTM_TOCPAGE">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<P>
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
</TABLE>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT">
<A NAME="O15894EXV3_HTM_104">
</A>
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
<I>
	TRENDS IN THE NUCLEAR POWER INDUSTRY
</I>
</B>
<BR>
<BR>
	A number of evolving trends in the nuclear power industry have the potential to affect
	Cameco&#146;s uranium and conversion businesses.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Current Status and Growth
<BR>
<BR>
	Reactors &#151; Operating, Planned and Under Construction
<BR>
<BR>
</B>
	There are 439 reactors operating worldwide, and a total of 69 new reactors that are under
	construction or planned for completion within the next 10&nbsp;years (as of January&nbsp;2005). This more
	than offsets 38 planned closures for a net increase of 31 reactors during the period. Planned
	changes in the number of reactors include:
<P>
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="3%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	In Asia, 42 new reactors are offset by 4 closures for a net increase of 38 reactors as
	energy demand responds to rapid economic expansion. Half of this growth will occur in
	China and India with plans for an increase of 11 and 9 reactors respectively.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD COLSPAN="5">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="3%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	In Eastern Europe, it is anticipated that 14 new reactors will begin operating and four
	existing reactors close for a net increase of 10 reactors.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD COLSPAN="5">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="3%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	In Western Europe, nine countries are expected to close 29 reactors, with most of the
	closures occurring in the UK and Germany. Only Finland and France are building new plants,
	bringing the net loss to 27.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD COLSPAN="5">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="3%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	In the US, the Tennessee Valley Authority is proceeding with a restart program for Unit
	1 of its Browns Ferry nuclear station.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD COLSPAN="5">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="3%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	In Canada, Ontario Power Generation Inc. (OPG)&nbsp;plans to restart three Pickering units
	(one restart is currently approved). Although not included in the growth projections above,
	our Bruce Power partnership is assessing the feasibility of restarting its remaining two
	&#147;A&#148; units.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD COLSPAN="5">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="3%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	Other countries plan to start seven new reactors, offset by one closure for six
	additional reactors beginning operations during this period.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Pending
</B>
<BR>
<BR>
	Several non-nuclear countries including Indonesia, Turkey, Egypt, Vietnam and Kazakhstan are
	considering nuclear programs.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Plant Performance
<BR>
<BR>
	Capacity Factors
<BR>
<BR>
</B>
	In 2004, the global gross average capacity factor among nuclear generators rose to almost 79% from
	76% in 2003. The increase was due to record setting performance by nuclear plants in the US and
	Sweden, Japan&#146;s recovery from a number of shutdowns required by regulators, and a full year&#146;s
	performance from three reactors in Canada that had been laid up for several years. Global capacity
	factors were also affected by good reactor performance in several
	other countries.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Operating Cost
<BR>
<BR>
</B>
	In 2003, the latest year for which data is available, the direct costs of US nuclear electricity
	production were lower than coal and second only to hydro for the fifth consecutive year. US nuclear
	production costs were 1.7 cents per kilowatt-hour, 1.8 cents for coal, and more than 5.5 cents for
	oil and gas.
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	6
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage172"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
<A HREF="#O15894EXV3_HTM_TOCPAGE">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Nuclear Acceptance
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Positive Trends
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<I>
	North America
<BR>
</I>
	Public support for nuclear power in the US is trending higher. A poll, conducted by the Nuclear
	Energy Institute in 2004, showed that 67% of people favoured the use of nuclear power. The US
	Department of Energy&#146;s (DOE)&nbsp;2004 strategic plan includes an initiative to support the ordering of
	at least one new nuclear reactor in the 2010 timeframe. In response, three industry consortia have
	been formed to advance the licensing of new reactor models. This should result in the certification
	of an advanced reactor design that will qualify for combined construction and operating licences,
	thereby positioning consortia members to proceed with construction.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	The market for US nuclear generation assets has become more competitive. Capital markets have
	become receptive to financing nuclear generation. In its most recent global energy outlook, the US
	DOE has again projected a greater role (relative to its previous forecast) for nuclear power over
	the next 15&nbsp;years.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	In Canada, the restart of OPG&#146;s Pickering Unit 1 was approved in recognition of the need for
	nuclear power to support demand growth and clean-air initiatives. Private investment is expected to
	play a significant role in developing Ontario&#146;s nuclear capacity.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<I>
	Europe
<BR>
</I>
	The link between clean air and nuclear power is increasingly recognized by influential non-nuclear
	entities including the European Commission&#146;s research department. In addition, leading
	international environmentalists, such as James Lovelock, Hugh Montefiore and Patrick Moore, are
	emerging as strong advocates of new nuclear construction.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	The Prime Minister of the United Kingdom recently acknowledged that new nuclear construction must
	be considered in the UK&#146;s plans to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Several countries including the US and the UK, along with the European Union (EU)&nbsp;have recognized
	the strategic risk of over-reliance on natural gas. The International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)
	has launched an international research initiative on the development of small reactors.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Negative Trends
<BR>
<BR>
</B>
	Nuclear phase-outs are mandated in Germany, Netherlands, Spain and Belgium, although reassessments
	are likely to continue. The Swedish government has terminated discussions with the Swedish nuclear
	power industry on an agreement for a nuclear phase-out policy and has ordered the shutdown of one
	reactor in May&nbsp;2005.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Safety problems and suspected cover up attempts have undermined public confidence in Japan&#146;s
	nuclear energy program, but Japan has recently announced that its nuclear energy capacity should
	double.
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	7
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage173"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
<A HREF="#O15894EXV3_HTM_TOCPAGE">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Although progress is being made in several countries on the management of radioactive waste from
	the nuclear fuel cycle, there remains strong opposition among the environmental community.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Summary of Trends
</B>
<BR>
<BR>
	The nuclear industry is experiencing stable growth in the form of capacity factor improvements,
	refurbishments, life extensions and, in Asia, aggressive new-build programs. It is difficult to
	determine which factors will dominate the outlook for nuclear in the long term. However, the demand
	for nuclear power is expected to grow even more significantly as increasing electricity demand, the
	need for non-emitting baseload energy and security of supply begin to take hold globally.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Overall, these indicators are expected to support a stable demand trend for uranium and conversion
	services in the next 10&nbsp;years with the potential for accelerated growth if nuclear energy continues
	to gain broader acceptance in the world.
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT">
<A NAME="O15894EXV3_HTM_105">
</A>
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
<I>
	URANIUM BUSINESS
</I>
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Worldwide Uranium Supply and Demand
</B>
<BR>
<BR>
	The uranium market supply and demand fundamentals continued to strengthen in 2004, indicating
	a need for more primary mine production over the coming decade. During the past 20&nbsp;years, uranium
	consumption has exceeded mine production by a wide margin, with the difference being made up by
	secondary supply sources such as various types of inventory and recycled products. While there are
	still inventories, they are considerably reduced and more may be classified as strategic rather
	than excess.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	In 2003, there were uranium production interruptions and supply announcements that caused utilities
	to re-examine their policy of maintaining low inventories. In addition, the weakening US dollar
	(compared to the currencies of almost all producer countries) meant that producers were realizing
	less revenue for each pound of uranium sold in US dollars. These factors contributed to the
	escalation of uranium prices in the last four months of 2003. In 2004, this upward trend
	continued, with spot prices increasing by 43% and long-term price indicators rising by 61%.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	However, for the most part, the strengthening uranium price reflects tightening supply and the
	recognition that new investment is needed to encourage exploration for additional reserves and to
	build new mines. Much of the known world uranium resources cannot be economically brought into
	production without higher prices. And due to low uranium prices over the past two decades, little
	exploration has been conducted. As a result of this under-investment in exploration, very few new
	discoveries have been made. Even with the production from these potential mines, there could be
	periods of supply tightness causing uranium prices to become quite volatile.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Sustained prices higher than what have been experienced over the past 10 to 20&nbsp;years are needed to
	ensure that production expands to meet growing requirements. We believe that over the next 10 to 20
	years, increased exploration and development will ensure enough uranium will be found and developed
	to supply an expanding nuclear power industry. Cameco is positioned to benefit
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	8
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage174"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
<A HREF="#O15894EXV3_HTM_TOCPAGE">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	through its control of more than 60% of new uranium production that is currently planned and
	through its continued support of exploration for new uranium deposits.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Uranium Demand
<BR>
<BR>
</B>
	Current nuclear power trends are generally positive. However, it is difficult to know whether
	these trends and the national debates on the long-term future of nuclear power will result in more
	or less favourable conditions for the nuclear industry. New plant construction, improved reactor
	operations, uprates and the extension of reactor lives make it highly likely that, at a minimum,
	the current demand for uranium will continue for several decades. In the near term, perceptions
	that uranium supplies are ample are beginning to change as excess inventories decline. Uranium
	prices have responded as spot prices rose during 2004 to $20.60 (US)&nbsp;per pound from $14.45 (US)&nbsp;a
	year earlier. As inventories continue to decrease, it is expected that uranium prices will more
	closely reflect the cost of primary mine production, including a reasonable return on new
	investment.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	World uranium consumption totalled about 180&nbsp;million pounds in 2004. Of that, western world
	consumption was about 159&nbsp;million pounds, up from an estimated 155&nbsp;million pounds largely as a
	result of members being added to the European Union. Cameco estimates that annual world uranium
	consumption will reach almost 210&nbsp;million pounds in 2014, reflecting an annual growth rate of 1.7%.
	Demand in Russia, Eastern Europe and China was about 21&nbsp;million pounds in 2004 and is expected to
	increase to about 35&nbsp;million pounds in 2014. Western world consumption is expected to increase to
	175&nbsp;million pounds in the 10-year period. In 2005, world demand is expected to increase to about
	184&nbsp;million pounds while western world demand is forecast to rise to 162&nbsp;million pounds.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	In 2004, eight reactors were connected to electricity grids, two each in South Korea and Ukraine,
	and one each in China, Japan, Russia and Canada. Three of these entered commercial operation in
	2004, with the remainder expected in 2005. There were five closures in 2004, four in the United
	Kingdom and one in Lithuania. The net result was a 6.2 gigawatt (GWe) increase in world nuclear
	capacity.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Uranium Supply
</B>
<BR>
<BR>
	World uranium supply comes from primary mine production and a number of secondary sources.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Mine Production
<BR>
<BR>
</B>
	World production in 2004 was about 104&nbsp;million pounds U
<SUB>
	3
</SUB>
	O
<SUB>
	8
</SUB>
	, up 12% from 93
	million pounds in 2003, largely as a result of Cameco&#146;s McArthur River mine recovering from
	operating difficulties in 2003. World production is expected to increase marginally in 2005.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	In 2004, the world&#146;s major uranium producers continued to be affected by the weakening US dollar.
	While most uranium is sold in US dollars, most of the world&#146;s production comes from outside the US.
	Uranium spot prices increased by 43% in 2004 and uranium long-term prices by 61%, but this was
	somewhat offset by the strength of other currencies against the US dollar. For example, the uranium
	spot price only increased by 33% in Canadian dollars in 2004, 37% in Australian dollars, and 22% in
	South African rand. The countries affected by these currency changes produced about 61% of world
	production in 2004. As a consequence, this trend in
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	9
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage175"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
<A HREF="#O15894EXV3_HTM_TOCPAGE">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	relative currency values has increased the need for sustained higher prices to stimulate
	exploration and new production.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Secondary Sources
<BR>
<BR>
</B>
	Secondary sources of supply consist of surplus military materials, excess inventory and recycled
	products. Recycled products include reprocessed uranium, mixed oxide fuel and re-enriched tails
	material. Some utilities use reprocessed uranium and mixed oxide fuel from used reactor fuel. In
	recent years, another source of supply has been re-enriched depleted uranium tails generated using
	excess enrichment capacity. We estimate that these recycled products will account for about 8% of
	western world demand over the next 10&nbsp;years. With the exception of recycled material, secondary
	supplies are finite. Recycled products are currently a high-cost fuel alternative and are used by
	utilities in only a few countries.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	One of the largest sources of secondary supply is the uranium derived from Russian highly enriched
	uranium (HEU). As a result of the 1993 HEU agreement between the US and Russia to reduce the number
	of nuclear weapons, additional supplies of uranium have been available to the market. Under the
	20-year agreement, weapons-grade HEU is blended down in Russia to low enriched uranium (LEU)
	capable of being used in western world nuclear power plants. Uranium derived from Russian HEU could
	meet 11% of western world demand over the next 10&nbsp;years.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	The other large source of secondary supply is excess inventories. Prior to 1985, uranium mine
	production exceeded reactor requirements due, in large part, to government incentive programs that
	anticipated rapid growth of nuclear generated electricity. The result was a buildup of large
	inventories, both in the commercial and government sectors. Over the past 20&nbsp;years, uranium mine
	production has been less than annual requirements and the company believes that most of these
	inventories have been consumed.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Cameco estimates the drawdown in 2004 of excess inventory held by western world utilities,
	producers, governments and other industry participants was in the range of 25&nbsp;million pounds
	U
<SUB>
	3
</SUB>
	O
<SUB>
	8
</SUB>
	. Inventory drawdown in 2005 is expected to be somewhat lower than in
	2004, reflecting declining inventory availability.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Uranium Markets
</B>
<BR>
<BR>
	Utilities secure the majority of their uranium requirements (80% to 90% in recent years) by
	entering into medium-term (three to five years) and long-term (more than five years) contracts with
	uranium suppliers. These contracts usually provide for deliveries to begin two to three years after
	contracts are finalized. In awarding contracts, utilities consider the commercial terms offered,
	including price, and the producer&#146;s record of performance and uranium reserves.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	There are a number of pricing formulas, including base prices adjusted by inflation indices,
	reference prices (generally spot price indicators but also long-term reference prices) and annual
	price negotiations. Many contracts also contain floor prices, ceiling prices and other negotiated
	provisions that affect the amount ultimately paid.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Utilities acquire the remainder of their uranium requirements through spot and near-term purchases
	from producers and traders. Spot market purchases are those that call for delivery
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	10
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage176"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
<A HREF="#O15894EXV3_HTM_TOCPAGE">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	within one year. Traders generally source their uranium from organizations holding excess
	inventory, including utilities, producers and governments.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Uranium Spot Market
<BR>
<BR>
</B>
	Spot market volume for 2004 totalled 18&nbsp;million pounds of uranium, about 18% less than the 22
	million pounds in 2003. The spot market represented about 11% of the western world&#146;s uranium
	consumption in 2004, a modest decrease from 2003.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Lower spot demand in 2004 can be attributed to buyers with near-term requirements exercising upward
	volume flexibilities under existing contracts in an effort to avoid the higher prices in the spot
	market. In 2004, about 88% of spot market transactions were conducted off-market as buyers
	attempted to minimize upward pressure on prices. Discretionary buying represented a higher
	proportion of spot buying in 2004 than in 2003, indicating that some market participants anticipate
	continued spot price increases.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Over 2004, the spot price increased by 43% to end the year at $20.60 (US)&nbsp;per pound of uranium.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Looking to 2005, we expect spot uranium demand to be about the same level as 2004. Utilities&#146;
	requirements are generally well covered for 2005 and early 2006. Where uncovered requirements
	exist, Cameco expects utilities will, to the extent they can, take advantage of upward quantity
	flexibilities under older, lower priced contracts, rather than come to the spot market.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	The recent trend of spot transactions being conducted quietly off-market is expected to continue in
	2005. As was the case in 2004, there are a limited number of sellers with supply available for sale
	in the spot market in 2005.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Long-Term Uranium Market
</B>
<BR>
<BR>
	Long-term contracting in 2004 is estimated to have been about 90&nbsp;million pounds of uranium, an
	increase over the 75&nbsp;million pounds estimated for 2003.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	The industry average long-term price (according to industry sources TradeTech and Ux) on December
	31, 2004 was $25.00 (US)&nbsp;per pound of uranium, up from $23.00 (US)&nbsp;at the end of the third quarter,
	and $15.50 (US)&nbsp;at the end of 2003.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	We expect long-term contracting activity in 2005 will remain at about this level, as those
	utilities that have attempted to wait for prices to decline will be required to go to the market to
	begin filling uncovered requirements.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Dynamics have shifted to a more seller-oriented market, and we expect sellers will increasingly
	prefer to enter into longer-term deals. At the same time, some utilities, in particular those that
	are looking at the market fundamentals more strategically, and are concerned about supply beyond
	the end of this decade, are also interested in entering into longer-term contracts with sellers
	that can offer reliable supply over the longer term.
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	11
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage177"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
<A HREF="#O15894EXV3_HTM_TOCPAGE">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Uranium Business &#151; Key Performance Drivers
</B>
<BR>
<BR>
	The major factors that drive Cameco&#146;s uranium business results are:
<P>
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="1%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	prices &#151; spot and long-term,
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD COLSPAN="5">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>

<TD WIDTH="1%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	volume &#151; sales, production, purchases,

	&nbsp;

	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;

	costs &#151; production and purchases, and

	&nbsp;
</TD>

<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="1%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	the relationship between the US and Canadian dollars.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Prices &#151; Spot/Long-Term
<BR>
<BR>
	Background
</B>
<BR>
<BR>
	While Cameco generally does not sell uranium in the spot market, about 60% of the company&#146;s uranium
	under its long-term contracts is sold at prices that reference the spot market price near the time
	of delivery. The remaining 40% is sold at fixed prices or base prices escalated by an inflation
	index. Uranium is priced in US dollars per pound U
<SUB>
	3
</SUB>
	O
<SUB>
	8
</SUB>
	.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Most of the company&#146;s spot market-related contracts were entered into a number of years ago when
	the average spot price was half the 2004&nbsp;year-end price of $20.60 (US)&nbsp;per pound. These contracts
	generally contain ceiling prices. Due to the rapid increase in the uranium spot price in the latter
	part of 2003 and in 2004, a number of spot-market-related contracts reached ceiling prices. The
	impact of ceiling prices became significant as the spot price moved into the $14.00 (US)&nbsp;range.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Many of Cameco&#146;s fixed/base-price contracts were also entered into during the same period, when the
	long-term price indicator averaged less than $11.00 (US)&nbsp;per pound compared to the 2004 average of
	more than $20.00 (US)&nbsp;per pound. Long-term price indicators provide guidance on the level of fixed
	prices being signed in the long-term contract market. As a result, some of Cameco&#146;s current
	fixed-price contracts reflect the low long-term prices from the earlier periods.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	The benefit of improved spot prices was partially offset by a less favourable foreign exchange
	rate. As a result, Cameco&#146;s average realized price for uranium sales was $12.89 (US)&nbsp;per pound of
	uranium compared to an average spot price of $18.60 (US)&nbsp;and average long-term price of $20.00 (US)
	in 2004.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Uranium Price Sensitivity 2005
</B>
<BR>
<BR>
	For deliveries in 2005, a $1.00 (US)&nbsp;per pound change in the U
<SUB>
	3
</SUB>
	O
<SUB>
	8
</SUB>
	spot price
	from the year-end level of $20.60 (US)&nbsp;per pound would change revenue by about $5&nbsp;million (Cdn),
	net earnings by about $3&nbsp;million (Cdn) and cash flows by about $4&nbsp;million. This sensitivity assumes
	that 1.00 US dollar is equivalent to 1.32 Canadian dollars. Please see uranium price sensitivity
	discussion below.
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	12
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage178"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
<A HREF="#O15894EXV3_HTM_TOCPAGE">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Uranium Price Sensitivity Analysis 2005 to 2008
</B>
<BR>
<BR>
	The impact of the current higher spot prices and long-term price indicators will benefit Cameco in
	the longer term as the company delivers uranium in the future under new contracts signed in the
	current environment.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Of note, at the end of 2004, the average uranium spot price was $20.60 (US), while the long-term
	price indicator was $25.00 (US). Historically, long-term prices have generally been at a premium of
	$1.00 to $2.00 over prevailing spot prices. At the end of 2004, that difference was about $4.00
	(US)&nbsp;per pound. This spread is the consequence of the relatively low level of activity in the spot
	market over the last year or so, compared to the higher level of activity in the long-term market.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Current market fundamentals suggest that both spot and long-term prices should continue to
	strengthen, and we expect the spot price to move up somewhat more than the long-term price, so that
	the differential will move back to the more traditional spread of $1.00 to $2.00 (US).
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Given the level of sales targeted each year (33&nbsp;million pounds in 2005), the company is continually
	in the market signing new contracts for deliveries that will begin two to three years hence. About
	25% to 30% of the current contract portfolio expires each year, and is replaced in large part with
	contracts that were entered into in the past two to three years.
<BR>
	During this period of increasing spot and long-term prices, the company has continued to enter into
	new multi-year contracts with improved terms. The new contract portfolio will reflect a mix of
	fixed and market-related prices. For the time being, Cameco continues to target its traditional
	blend of pricing mechanisms, that is, 40% of sales volume with fixed pricing and 60% sensitive to
	market pricing. Contracts with market-related pricing will reference the spot or long-term price
	indicators quoted near the time of delivery. These market-related contracts typically contain
	ceiling and floor prices. However, in recent months, we have been offering ceiling prices much
	higher than current spot prices, if at all. We have also been negotiating floor price protection,
	which has been in the range of current spot prices.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	The fixed-price contracts will have prices that were fixed at the time of contract signing. This
	means the company has contracts at fixed prices below and above the current spot market prices and
	they fall into the category of &#147;insensitive&#148; to market price.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	We believe this contract mix continues to be appropriate given our view that market prices will
	strengthen. At the same time, this contract mix allows us to lock in the significant differential
	between current spot and long-term prices, and provides firm support for our growth strategy.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	The following table indicates the approximate percentage of targeted sales volume that will be
	impacted by further increases in the market price above $20.60 (US)&nbsp;per pound
	U
<SUB>
	3
</SUB>
	O
<SUB>
	8
</SUB>
	. As shown in the table below, the proportion of targeted sales that is
	sensitive to further increases in the market price grows significantly in 2006 and continues in
	2007 and 2008.
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	13
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>

<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">

</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="96%">
	fixed-price contracts and market-related contracts not sensitive to increases in
	the spot price above year-end 2004 level of $20.60 (US)&nbsp;per pound
<BR>
<BR>
	market-related contracts plus uncommitted volumes
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Volume &#151; Sales, Production, Purchases
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Sales Volume
<BR>
</B>
	In 2004, Cameco sold more than 32&nbsp;million pounds of uranium, representing a 9% decline from
	last year&#146;s record quantity of 35&nbsp;million pounds. Sales volumes were deliberately reduced to better
	reflect production and desired inventory levels. Cameco&#146;s uranium sales volumes are expected to
	total more than 33&nbsp;million pounds in 2005.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	For the five-year period 2005 to 2009, Cameco has more than 120&nbsp;million pounds of uranium sales
	committed. Of these sales commitments, about 70% will be delivered during 2005 to 2007. Cameco&#146;s
	committed sales decline rapidly after 2007 and they will be replaced in the normal course with new
	contracts reflecting prevailing market conditions at the time they are completed.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Cameco sells more uranium than it produces from its mines. Cameco&#146;s sales commitments are filled by
	a combination of sources consisting of mine production, long-term purchase arrangements, spot
	purchases and inventory.
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_88"></A>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">

	Production Volume
</B>

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	McArthur River/Key Lake
<BR>
<BR>
</B>
	Production at McArthur River/Key Lake totalled 18.7&nbsp;million pounds of uranium in 2004, 24% higher
	than in 2003. Cameco&#146;s share was 70% or 13.1&nbsp;million pounds. The increase was due to McArthur River
	producing for a full year, whereas in 2003 operating difficulties required the mine to be shut down
	for three months.
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	14
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage180"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
<A HREF="#O15894EXV3_HTM_TOCPAGE">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	The Canadian Nuclear Safety Commission (CNSC)&nbsp;approved renewal of the operating licences for Key
	Lake and McArthur River on October&nbsp;25, 2004 until October&nbsp;31, 2008.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Cameco
	has applied for an increase in the annual licenced capacity at McArthur River and Key Lake to 22
	million pounds per year compared to 18.7&nbsp;million pounds currently. The CNSC has indicated that the
	application will require a screening level environmental assessment (EA)&nbsp;under the Canadian
	Environmental Assessment Act. We are hopeful for a decision from the CNSC late in 2005. If approval
	is received, Cameco expects it will take about two years to ramp up production. We are developing a
	plan to determine the optimal sustainable production rate, which may be less than the licensed
	capacity.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Production at McArthur River/Key Lake in 2005 is expected to remain at the same level as 2004.
	Production would increase modestly if the CNSC approves the capacity increases at these facilities
	in late 2005.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Rabbit Lake
<BR>
<BR>
</B>
	Rabbit Lake produced 5.4&nbsp;million pounds U
<SUB>
	3
</SUB>
	O
<SUB>
	8
</SUB>
	in 2004, down 8% from 2003. The
	decrease was due mainly to difficult mining conditions resulting in reduced mill feed.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Significant exploration drilling occurred in 2004 with over 52,500 metres drilled. The program has
	been successful to date, extending mine life to 2007. Additional underground and surface drilling
	will take place in 2005.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Rabbit Lake production is expected to increase modestly in 2005 over 2004
<B>
	.
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Smith Ranch-Highland and Crow Butte
<BR>
<BR>
</B>
	The Smith Ranch-Highland (Wyoming) and Crow Butte (Nebraska) in-situ leach (ISL)&nbsp;mines produced a
	total of 2.0&nbsp;million pounds of uranium in 2004. Production is expected to increase 15% in 2005 to
	2.3&nbsp;million pounds. We are planning to at least double production from Wyoming over the next
	several years to help meet the need for new uranium supply.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Uranium Projects
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Cigar Lake
</B>
<BR>
<BR>
	On December&nbsp;21, 2004, after receiving a licence from the CNSC to construct a facility, the Cigar
	Lake joint venture decided to proceed with construction of the mine. Construction began on January
	1, 2005 and will take about 27&nbsp;months to complete. Assuming production begins in 2007, there will
	be a ramp up period of up to three years before the mine reaches expected full production of 18
	million pounds per year. Cameco&#146;s share is 50%.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	In making the development decision, the Cigar Lake joint venture approved a construction budget of
	$450&nbsp;million (Cameco&#146;s share is $225&nbsp;million) that includes surface and underground facilities at
	Cigar Lake as well as changes to the milling facilities at McClean Lake and Rabbit Lake. Proposed
	changes to the Rabbit Lake and McClean Lake facilities are subject to regulatory approvals.
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	15
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage181"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
<A HREF="#O15894EXV3_HTM_TOCPAGE">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Inkai
<BR>
<BR>
</B>
	The ISL test mine at Inkai in Kazakhstan produced 0.47&nbsp;million pounds of uranium in 2004 (Cameco&#146;s
	share is 60%).
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	The Inkai Joint Venture has decided to proceed with construction of the Inkai ISL mine. The joint
	venture intends to submit an environmental assessment and a design plan for the commercial facility
	to Kazakh regulatory authorities in the first half of 2005, with approval expected by third quarter
	2005. Following approval, construction will begin with commercial production scheduled for late
	2007. The Inkai Joint Venture has notified the Kazakh government that it intends to increase
	production to 5.2&nbsp;million pounds per year at full capacity, up from the previous plan of 2.6
	million pounds. The costs, net of sales proceeds from Inkai&#146;s test production, are capitalized
	until commercial production is achieved. The test mine at Inkai is projected to produce 0.45
	million pounds of uranium in 2005.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	The capital cost, excluding sales proceeds, to bring the new ISL mine to production is now
	estimated at $83&nbsp;million (US), up from the earlier estimate of $38&nbsp;million (US). The increase is
	due to the decision to double the plant production capacity and to increases in the costs of
	construction materials and plant equipment. Cameco has agreed to fund up to $40&nbsp;million (US)&nbsp;of
	development, which includes the original test mine, with an interest-bearing loan. The Inkai Joint
	Venture will fund the remainder. Repayment of the principal amount of the loan is expected to start
	once commercial production commences. The Inkai Joint Venture is obligated to repay the loan and
	interest. To the end of 2004, Cameco had advanced $28&nbsp;million (US).
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_89"></A>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Uranium Exploration
<BR>
<BR>
</B>
	Cameco carries out mineral exploration for new uranium resources on substantial land holdings,
	principally located in two areas: the Athabasca basin of northern Saskatchewan and the Arnhem Land
	region in Northern Territory, Australia. The subdivision of lands (properties in which Cameco holds
	interests greater than 10%) and uranium exploration expenditures is as follows:

<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	The majority of Cameco&#146;s exploration lands are explored as joint ventures with other mining
	companies, most often with Cogema Resources Inc. At year-end 2004, Cameco operated about 80% of its exploration
	projects, including joint ventures. The majority of Cameco&#146;s exploration projects are early to
	middle stage, on which indications of economic grades and quantities of uranium have not yet been
	identified.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	In 2004, Cameco also carried out surface exploration near existing mines, specifically the Rabbit
	Lake and McArthur River operations, with the intent to locate new resources that could be
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	16
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage182"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
<A HREF="#O15894EXV3_HTM_TOCPAGE">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	developed to expand or extend these operations. This exploration, followed by underground drilling,
	was successful at Rabbit Lake adding 6.1&nbsp;million pounds of probable reserves. Work on another
	advanced exploration project, the Cree Extension project, has advanced the Millennium discovery,
	initially made in 2000, to an indicated and inferred resource. For more information on the
	resources, see Cameco&#146;s 2004 annual information form.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Cameco owned a 25.2% interest in UEX Corporation at December&nbsp;31, 2004, a TSX-listed junior
	exploration company formed in 2002 from a combination of exploration assets previously held by
	Cameco and Pioneer Metals Corporation. Cameco has certain rights related to financing, milling, and
	marketing future uranium deposits discovered by UEX. Once Cameco&#146;s interest falls below 20%, these
	special rights end. At December&nbsp;31, 2004, the market value of Cameco&#146;s interest in UEX was about
	$81&nbsp;million.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Since many areas of the world are known to host numerous types of uranium mineralization, Cameco
	actively investigates the uranium exploration potential of areas other than those described above.
	No major exploration projects are currently being undertaken in areas outside Canada and Australia.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Purchases
<BR>
</B>
<BR>
	Cameco also has purchase commitments for uranium products and services from various sources.
	At the end of 2004, these purchase commitments totalled 71&nbsp;million pounds uranium equivalent (most
	is in the form of UF
<SUB>
	6
</SUB>
	) from 2005 to 2013. Of this, 60&nbsp;million pounds is from exercising
	options under our agreement to purchase uranium from dismantled Russian weapons (the Russian HEU
	commercial agreement).
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Costs
<BR>
</B>
<BR>
	Cameco&#146;s cost of supply is influenced by its mix of produced mine material and uranium
	purchases.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Production costs at our Saskatchewan uranium mines, our largest source of production, are primarily
	fixed, with the largest component being labour. The largest variable operating cost is production
	supplies, followed by maintenance materials.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Uranium mine production costs are driven mostly by the complexity of the operation. Unit costs of
	production are driven primarily by the grade and size of the reserves. McArthur River is the
	world&#146;s largest, high-grade uranium mine. Its ore grade averages 25% U
<SUB>
	3
</SUB>
	O
<SUB>
	8
</SUB>
	which means it can produce more than 18&nbsp;million pounds per year by extracting only 100 to 120
	tonnes of ore per day. While Rabbit Lake&#146;s average ore grade of 1% U
<SUB>
	3
</SUB>
	O
<SUB>
	8
</SUB>
	is
	much lower, it compares favourably to other operating mines in the world that have ore grades
	generally below 0.5%.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	ISL extraction methods can make even lower-grade orebodies commercially attractive. Worldwide, ISL
	mines typically recover uranium from orebodies with an average grade in the range of 0.1%
	U
<SUB>
	3
</SUB>
	O
<SUB>
	8
</SUB>
	. Cameco&#146;s cost of supply is influenced only modestly by the two US ISL
	operations, as the production from the ISL operations accounts for a small percentage of its total
	primary output. In 2005, US ISL production is expected to account for about 11% of the company&#146;s
	planned primary output.
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	17
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage183"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
<A HREF="#O15894EXV3_HTM_TOCPAGE">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Purchased product also affects Cameco&#146;s cost of supply. The majority of Cameco&#146;s purchase
	commitments are under long-term, fixed-price arrangements reflecting prices significantly lower
	than the current published spot and long-term prices. These purchase commitments totalled $1,086
	million at December&nbsp;31, 2004. See note 21(d) to the consolidated financial statements. A
	significant portion of these purchased pounds will be delivered into existing sales contracts.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Foreign Exchange
<BR>
</B>
<BR>
	The relationship between the Canadian and US dollars affects the financial results of the
	uranium business as well as the conversion business. For that reason, the effect on both businesses
	will be discussed in this section.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	In 2004, the strengthening of the Canadian dollar against the US dollar affected Cameco&#146;s results.
	Cameco sells the majority of its uranium and conversion services in US dollars while most of its
	uranium and conversion services are produced in Canada. As such, the company&#146;s uranium and
	conversion services revenue is denominated mostly in US dollars, while its production costs are
	denominated primarily in Canadian dollars.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	The company attempts to provide some protection against exchange rate fluctuations by planned
	hedging activity designed to smooth volatility. Therefore, Cameco&#146;s uranium and conversion revenues
	are partly sheltered against declines in the US dollar in the shorter term.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	In addition, Cameco has a portion of its annual cash outlays denominated in US dollars, including
	uranium and conversion services purchases, which provide a natural hedge against US currency
	fluctuations. While natural hedges provide cash flow protection against exchange rate fluctuations,
	the influence on earnings from purchased material that has been inventoried may be dispersed over
	several fiscal periods and is more difficult to identify.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	During 2004, the Canadian dollar strengthened against the US dollar from $1.2924 at December
	31, 2003 to $1.2036 at December&nbsp;31, 2004.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	At December&nbsp;31, 2004, Cameco had a foreign currency hedge portfolio of $748&nbsp;million (US). The
	schedule of designations, by year, is as follows:
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER">
<TABLE STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT" CELLSPACING="0" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%">

</DIV>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	These hedges are expected to yield an average exchange rate of $1.3010. The net mark-to-market gain
	on these hedge positions was $68&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2004.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	For 2004, $255&nbsp;million (US)&nbsp;of Cameco&#146;s uranium and conversion revenue was hedged using currency
	contracts at an average rate of $1.4732. As of December&nbsp;31, 2004, about 75% of 2005 uranium and
	conversion revenue was hedged using currency contracts expecting to yield an average rate of
	$1.3214.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 0%; TEXT-INDENT: 0%; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	For 2005, every one-cent change in the US to Canadian dollar exchange rate would change net
	earnings by about $2&nbsp;million (Cdn).
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	18
</DIV>

	million. The schedule for deferred revenue to be released to earnings, by year, is as follows:

<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Uranium Strategies
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Cameco&#146;s overall objective is to build on and leverage our competitive advantage in uranium.
	In doing so, we strive to meet three major goals:
<P>
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="1%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	maintain our low-cost position,
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD COLSPAN="5">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="1%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	protect and grow our market position, and
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD COLSPAN="5">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="1%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	improve our supply flexibility.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	There are a number of key strategies the company uses to achieve its goals:
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Maintain our low-cost position by:
</B>
<P>
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="1%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	adding low-cost reserves:
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P>
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="3%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	through acquisition,
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD COLSPAN="5">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="3%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	exploration around existing operations as well as in current and new regions of
	interest, and
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD COLSPAN="5">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="3%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	by validating the potential for competitive ISL production from existing properties.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P>
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="1%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	improving margins by:
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P>
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="3%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	adjusting the rate of production to yield the highest rate of return,
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD COLSPAN="5">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="3%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	gaining cost efficiencies through quality and business process improvements, and
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD COLSPAN="5">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="3%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	pursuing fundamental productivity gains through technological development.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Protect and grow our market position by:
</B>
<P>
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="1%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	leveraging industry relationships to participate in new production,
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD COLSPAN="5">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="1%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	ensuring sustainable production by identifying and exploring for new uranium reserves,
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD COLSPAN="5">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="1%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	seeking appropriate acquisitions, and
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD COLSPAN="5">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="1%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	developing customer relationships and expanding the range of services currently available while enhancing
	the company&#146;s reputation as a secure supplier.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Improve supply flexibility by:
</B>
<P>
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="1%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	bringing on Cigar Lake and Inkai production in timely fashion,
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD COLSPAN="5">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="1%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	continuing to pursue a global exploration program, and
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD COLSPAN="5">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="1%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	securing additional secondary supplies.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	19
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage185"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
<A HREF="#O15894EXV3_HTM_TOCPAGE">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<P>
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
</TABLE>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
<I>
	Capability to Deliver Results
</I>
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Cameco will continue to enhance capabilities in a number of areas to execute our strategies
	and deliver on our goals. We need to ensure that:
<P>
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="3%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	other mining methods continue to be advanced to allow us to maintain or expand our
	annual production,
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD COLSPAN="5">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="3%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	skilled tradespeople will continue to be available,
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD COLSPAN="5">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="3%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	adequate human resources are available to replace an aging workforce,
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD COLSPAN="5">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="3%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	capital is readily available over the longer term given our expansion plans, and
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD COLSPAN="5">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="3%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	adequate resources are allocated to exploration.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Mining Methods
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Currently, McArthur River uses raise boring to extract ore from the mine. As we anticipated
	from the start of mining, other mining methods may be used to maintain or expand production. We
	continue to examine and advance other mining methods.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	We also plan to use the jet boring method at Cigar Lake, which has been tested through test mining
	programs. We continue to advance this technology as we move towards Cigar Lake startup.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Skilled Tradespeople
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Cameco has significant experience in developing uranium mines. The biggest challenge in
	meeting our Cigar Lake construction timetable is in securing skilled tradespeople who are currently
	in short supply. This shortage affects all of our operations. Cameco is examining various options
	to build on our extensive apprenticeship programs.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Human Resources
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Canada&#146;s workforce is aging. Cameco&#146;s challenge is to compete for the limited number of people
	entering the workforce to replace retiring employees. Approximately 26% of the workforce at our
	Saskatchewan uranium mines was age 50 or more at December&nbsp;31, 2004. We are developing a people
	strategy to meet that challenge.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Ready Access to Capital
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Cameco has an ambitious plan to grow in the nuclear energy industry. Opportunities to invest
	are unpredictable and often capital intensive. We intend to maintain financial flexibility to
	pursue opportunities as they arise. For that reason, we maintain a conservative financial structure
	with a target of no more than 25% net debt to total capital.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Exploration Programs
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Cameco maintained an exploration program during the depressed price cycles to retain uranium
	exploration expertise. However, more funding is required to achieve our goal of increasing our
	reserve base to grow our uranium market leadership position.
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	20
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage186"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
<A HREF="#O15894EXV3_HTM_TOCPAGE">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Cameco plans to invest about $23&nbsp;million in uranium exploration during 2005 as part of its
	long-term strategy to maintain its leadership position in uranium production. In 2004, uranium
	exploration expenditures were about $17&nbsp;million, up $4&nbsp;million from 2003.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Cameco is pursuing a focused exploration program to identify additional uranium reserves for the
	future to maintain the company&#146;s position as the world&#146;s largest uranium producer.
