</DIV>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Cameco&#146;s uranium business consists of the McArthur River, Key Lake and Rabbit Lake mine/mill
	operations in Saskatchewan, two ISL mines in the US, the Inkai ISL test mine in Kazakhstan, the
	Cigar Lake development project in Saskatchewan and uranium exploration projects located primarily
	in Canada and Australia.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Revenue
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	In 2004, Cameco established a new record for uranium revenue for the third consecutive year.
	Revenue from the uranium business increased by 2% to $581&nbsp;million from $570&nbsp;million in 2003, due to
	a 12% increase in the realized selling price reflected in Canadian dollars. This improvement was
	the result of an increase in the uranium spot price, which averaged $18.60 (US)&nbsp;in 2004 compared to
	$11.54 (US)&nbsp;in 2003. The benefit of the improved spot price was partially offset by contract price
	ceilings and a less favourable foreign exchange rate.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Also offsetting the price improvement was a deliberate reduction in sales volume to better reflect
	production and inventory levels. In 2004, uranium deliveries amounted to about 32&nbsp;million pounds,
	representing a 9% decline from last year&#146;s record quantity of 35&nbsp;million pounds.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Cost of products and services sold
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	For 2004, the total cost of products and services sold was $378&nbsp;million compared to $394&nbsp;million in
	2003, reflecting the 9% decline in sales volume. On a per unit basis, the cost of product sold was
	about 5% higher than in the previous year. The cost of sales for 2003 included $24&nbsp;million in
	rehabilitation costs due to the mining difficulties at McArthur River. Excluding these costs and a
	$7&nbsp;million royalty recovery recorded in 2003, the unit cost of sale rose by 10% due to higher costs
	for purchased uranium and higher production costs at Rabbit Lake.
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	21
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage187"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
<A HREF="#O15894EXV3_HTM_TOCPAGE">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Depreciation, depletion and reclamation
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	In 2004, depreciation, depletion and reclamation (DD&#038;R) charges were $100&nbsp;million compared to $93
	million in 2003, due to a higher unit cost. On a per unit basis, costs rose by about 15% as the
	result of a higher proportion of sales of McArthur River and ISL material which carry a relatively
	higher DDR rates.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Gross profit
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	In 2004, gross profit from the uranium business amounted to $104&nbsp;million compared to $83&nbsp;million in
	2003, an increase of 25%. This was largely attributable to the higher spot price, which resulted in
	a 12% increase in the realized price and was partially offset by higher unit costs for uranium
	concentrates. Earnings before taxes from the uranium business increased by $21&nbsp;million in 2004 and
	the profit margin improved to 18% from 15% in 2003.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	2005 Outlook for Uranium
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	In 2005, Cameco&#146;s uranium revenue is expected to be about 10% higher than in 2004 due to a
	projected 6% improvement in the Canadian dollar selling price and a 4% increase in deliveries.
	Uranium sales volume is expected to total more than 33&nbsp;million pounds in 2005. About 35% of
	uranium deliveries are expected to occur in the last quarter of the year. In 2005, Cameco&#146;s share
	of uranium production is projected to increase to 21&nbsp;million pounds U
<SUB>
	3
</SUB>
	O
<SUB>
	8
</SUB>
	.
	Uranium margins are expected to improve to nearly 25% compared to 18% in 2004.
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT">
<A NAME="O15894EXV3_HTM_106">
</A>
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
<I>
	CONVERSION BUSINESS
</I>
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Conversion Demand
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	The demand for UF
<SUB>
	6
</SUB>
	conversion services is directly related to the level of
	electricity generated by light water nuclear power plants. The demand for UO
<SUB>
	2
</SUB>
	conversion
	services is linked to the level of electricity generated by Candu heavy water nuclear power plants.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	World demand for UF
<SUB>
	6
</SUB>
	and natural UO
<SUB>
	2
</SUB>
	conversion services was estimated to be
	about 68&nbsp;million kilograms of uranium (kgU) in 2004. Western world demand accounted for almost 60
	million kgU with the remaining 8&nbsp;million kgU coming from the non-western world (Russia, China and
	Eastern Europe).
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Over the next 10&nbsp;years, to 2014, western world demand is expected to increase by 12% to about 67
	million kgU and non-western world demand by 63% to about 13&nbsp;million kgU. In 2005, total world
	conversion demand is expected to increase by about 3% to 70&nbsp;million kgU.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Conversion Supply
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	The western world UF
<SUB>
	6
</SUB>
	conversion industry consists of Cameco and three other
	commercial producers with an annual capacity of about 45&nbsp;million kgU. Cameco&#146;s annual
	UF
<SUB>
	6
</SUB>
	conversion capacity constitutes about 28% of western world capacity.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	In 2001, British Nuclear Fuels Limited (BNFL), with annual conversion capacity of about 6&nbsp;million
	kgU, announced it would close its plant in 2006 and sold its uncommitted UF
<SUB>
	6
</SUB>
	production
	to Cameco.
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	22
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage188"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
<A HREF="#O15894EXV3_HTM_TOCPAGE">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	In addition, supplies are available from secondary sources including excess western inventories,
	Russian inventory sales in the form of low enriched uranium, Russian re-enriched depleted tails in
	the form of UF
<SUB>
	6
</SUB>
	and Russian and US uranium derived from dismantling nuclear weapons.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Russia supplies most of the UF
<SUB>
	6
</SUB>
	conversion requirements of the former Soviet Union and
	Eastern Europe in the form of low enriched uranium.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Conversion Markets
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Utilities contract more than 90% of their UF
<SUB>
	6
</SUB>
	conversion services through medium-
	and long-term contracts, purchasing the remainder on the spot market. Cameco is the only commercial
	supplier in the world of conversion for natural UO
<SUB>
	2
</SUB>
	customers. Cameco also exports
	UO
<SUB>
	2
</SUB>
	to South Korea for its Candu reactors and to the US and Japan for use as blanket
	fuel in boiling water reactors.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Spot/Long-Term Conversion Market
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Due to tightening of supply, spot prices for UF
<SUB>
	6
</SUB>
	rose by about 50% in 2004. The
	industry average spot market price (according to industry sources TradeTech and Ux) for North
	American uranium conversion services at December&nbsp;31, 2004 was $9.00 (US)&nbsp;per kgU, up 53% from the
	end of 2003. In Europe, the industry average spot conversion price was $10.00 (US)&nbsp;per kgU at
	December&nbsp;31, 2004, an increase of 48% from the end of 2003.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	The industry does not publish UO
<SUB>
	2
</SUB>
	prices.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Conversion Business &#151; Key Performance Drivers
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	The major factors that drive Cameco&#146;s conversion business results are:
<P>
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="1%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	prices &#151; spot and long-term,
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD COLSPAN="5">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="1%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	volume &#151; sales, production and purchases,
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD COLSPAN="5">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="1%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	costs &#151; production and purchases, and
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD COLSPAN="5">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="1%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	the relationship between the US and Canadian dollars.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Prices &#151; Spot/Long-Term
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Cameco sells its conversion services directly to utilities located in many parts of the world,
	primarily through medium- and long-term contracts. Conversion services are priced in US dollars per
	kgU. The majority of conversion sales are at base-escalated prices. Cameco&#146;s financial results for
	2005 are relatively insensitive to changes in the spot price for conversion. In 2004, most
	conversion sales did not benefit from the significant increase in UF
<SUB>
	6
</SUB>
	conversion spot
	prices during the year.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Going forward, nearly all contract commitments, for more than 50&nbsp;million kgU, have pricing terms
	that are base-price escalated.
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	23
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage189"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
<A HREF="#O15894EXV3_HTM_TOCPAGE">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Cameco continues to sign new long-term contracts with base prices that generally reflect
	longer-term prices at the time of the contract award. Therefore, in the coming years, Cameco&#146;s
	contract portfolio will be positively affected by these higher fixed-price contracts.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Volumes &#151; Sales, Production, Purchases
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Sales Volume
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Cameco sold a record 16.9&nbsp;million kgU in 2004, up marginally from 16.7&nbsp;million kgU in 2003.
	Conversion sales volume is expected to total about 16.2&nbsp;million kgU in 2005.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Production Volume
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	At Cameco&#146;s Port Hope facilities, conversion production totalled 9.5&nbsp;million kgU in 2004, down 29%
	compared to 2003. The decrease reflects the lengthy shutdown as a result of the summer vacation
	period, the seven-week labour disruption and some production rescheduling.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Production for 2005 is projected to be about 13.5&nbsp;million kgU, up 42% compared to 2004
<I>
	.
</I>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Purchase Volume
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Cameco also has purchase commitments, which primarily reflect the conversion component of the LEU
	from Russian HEU, re-enriched tails product and the company&#146;s agreement to purchase BNFL&#146;s excess
	production until the shutdown of its plant in 2006. Cameco&#146;s UF
<SUB>
	6
</SUB>
	conversion purchase
	commitments from 2005 to 2013 total about 27&nbsp;million kgU, most in the form of UF
<SUB>
	6
</SUB>
	.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Costs
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Cameco&#146;s mix of production and purchases influences its cost of supply. Conversion operating costs
	are primarily fixed with the largest component being labour. The largest variable operating cost is
	for anhydrous hydrogen fluoride, followed by energy (gas and electricity).
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	24
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage190"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
<A HREF="#O15894EXV3_HTM_TOCPAGE">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	The majority of Cameco&#146;s UF
<SUB>
	6
</SUB>
	conversion purchase commitments are under long-term,
	fixed-price arrangements reflecting prices lower than the current spot prices. A significant
	portion of these purchases have been committed under existing sales contracts.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Foreign Exchange
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	The majority of the company&#146;s conversion products are sold in the US and sales are denominated in
	US dollars, while production costs are incurred in Canada and denominated in Canadian dollars. As a
	result, the strengthening of the Canadian dollar against the US dollar in 2004 negatively affected
	Cameco&#146;s results. A discussion about Cameco&#146;s hedging program can be found in the uranium business
	section under the heading &#147;Foreign Exchange&#148;.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Conversion Strategies
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Cameco&#146;s objective is to build on and leverage its competitive advantage in conversion services. In doing so, it strives to meet three major goals:
<P>
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="1%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	maintain low-cost position,
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD COLSPAN="5">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="1%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	protect and grow its market position, and
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD COLSPAN="5">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="1%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	improve its supply flexibility.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	To achieve these goals, the company&#146;s strategies are to:
<P>
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="1%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	improve margins by gaining cost efficiencies through quality and business process improvements and
	pursuing productivity gains through technological development,
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD COLSPAN="5">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="1%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	grow market share through product diversification to meet changing nuclear fuel requirements,
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD COLSPAN="5">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="1%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	optimize capacity utilization to meet the growing need for new supply in the long term,
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD COLSPAN="5">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="1%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	pursue partnering and other opportunities with other nuclear fuel cycle participants, and
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD COLSPAN="5">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="1%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	secure secondary supplies.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Capability to Deliver Results
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Cameco is pursuing the opportunity provide a new fuel type to Bruce Power that will enhance
	its conversion supply capabilities. The Port Hope conversion facility currently supplies natural
	UO
<SUB>
	2
</SUB>
	powder for the manufacture of fuels for Candu reactors operating in Canada and other
	countries. The market for UO
<SUB>
	2
</SUB>
	is changing, at least partially, due to the planned
	introduction of slightly enriched uranium (SEU)&nbsp;in place of the natural uranium dioxide in some
	Candu reactors. SEU is a uranium dioxide powder that has an enrichment level up to 2.5% U-235, and
	is the primary uranium component of a new type of fuel that is proposed for use. The new fuel will
	increase the number of bundles as well as the concentration of U-235. This will result in an
	inherently safer design as the same amount of bundle power is distributed to more elements,
	reducing fuel element temperatures. The new design also incorporates a metal called dysprosium that
	will enhance the safety of the reactor by adding an additional braking feature. Commonly used in
	magnets and halogen lights, dysprosium has the ability to readily absorb neutrons and safely shut
	down a reactor.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Cameco&#146;s technology development group developed the process to produce SEU through blending,
	providing the company with an opportunity to participate in a changing market.
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	25
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage191"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
<A HREF="#O15894EXV3_HTM_TOCPAGE">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Our initial plan is to produce SEU for Bruce Power&#146;s B reactors as part of a power uprate project
	that is expected to add about 400 megawatts to Ontario&#146;s electricity grid, an increase of almost 9%
	over current capacity.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	In 2004, work continued toward regulatory approval of plans to produce SEU at Port Hope. The final
	environmental assessment (EA)&nbsp;study report was submitted for review in November to the CNSC and
	other agencies. The CNSC will gather the responses and prepare a draft screening report to be
	issued for public comment. The regulatory process was delayed by about six months by a peer review
	of the company&#146;s draft EA study report undertaken by the municipality of Port Hope in response to
	community concerns. The peer review conclusions generally supported the EA study report.
	Engineering work has continued on the detailed design of the SEU blending facility.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	The total annual quantity of SEU produced will depend on future market development. The SEU product
	would replace a limited volume of the current natural UO
<SUB>
	2
</SUB>
	product sales. Production of
	SEU at our Port Hope operation is subject to regulatory approval.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Cameco believes it has the appropriate capabilities in place to maintain its low-cost status,
	protect and grow its market position and improve its supply flexibility. We need to remain
	competitive in the longer-term and have the flexibility to quickly take advantage of future new
	market opportunities. Cameco is currently reviewing options to grow the conversion business to meet
	these longer-term opportunities.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	As with our uranium business, we need to ensure we have adequate human resources to replace the
	aging workforce. About 40% of the conversion services workforce was age 50 or more at December&nbsp;31,
	2004.We are developing a people strategy to meet that challenge.
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_91"></A>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Conversion Business Results
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Cameco&#146;s conversion business consists of the uranium refining and conversion facilities
	located in Ontario.

<!-- BEGIN TABLE BODY -->
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM" STYLE="BACKGROUND: #CCEEFF">
<TD WIDTH="1%" STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID #000000; BORDER-TOP: 1PX SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-TOP: 1PX SOLID #000000">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:15PX; TEXT-INDENT:-15PX">
	Revenue ($&nbsp;millions)
</DIV>
</TD>

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Revenue
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Revenue from the conversion business rose marginally in 2004 to $144&nbsp;million from $142&nbsp;million in
	2003 due to a 1% increase in selling price and a 1% increase in sales volume. Record annual
	conversion sales of 16.9&nbsp;million kgU were achieved.
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	26
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage192"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
<A HREF="#O15894EXV3_HTM_TOCPAGE">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Cost of products and services sold
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	In 2004, the cost of products and services sold was $102&nbsp;million compared to $92&nbsp;million in
	2003, an increase of 11% due to higher unit costs. In 2004, unit costs were adversely affected by a
	29% decline in production related to a labour dispute. Since it is Cameco&#146;s policy to account for
	its inventory on a weighted average basis, the unit cost of product sold tends to rise as
	production declines. On a per unit basis, the cost of products and services sold increased by about
	9% over the previous year.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Depreciation, depletion and reclamation
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	In 2004, depreciation, depletion and reclamation (DD&#038;R) charges were $10&nbsp;million compared to $11
	million in 2003. In spite of higher deliveries, total DD&#038;R declined compared to 2003 as sales in
	2004 included a higher proportion of purchased conversion.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Gross profit
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	In 2004, gross profit from the conversion business amounted to $33&nbsp;million compared to $40&nbsp;million
	in 2003, a decrease of 18%. This decline was largely attributable to the higher unit cost of
	product sold. The gross profit margin for the conversion business declined to 23% from 28% in 2003.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Conversion Services Outlook for 2005
</B>
<BR>
<BR>
	Revenue from the conversion business is likely to be marginally higher than in 2004 due to an
	expected 5% increase in the average realized selling price, partially offset by a forecast 4%
	reduction in deliveries. Conversion sales volume is expected to total about 16.2&nbsp;million kgU in
	2005 compared to 16.9&nbsp;million kgU in 2004. Production for 2005 is projected to be about 13.5
	million kgU, up from 9.5&nbsp;million kgU in 2004. As a result, unit costs are expected to be lower than
	in 2004, improving the profit margin.
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT">
<A NAME="O15894EXV3_HTM_107">
</A>
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
<I>
	NUCLEAR ELECTRICITY BUSINESS
</I>
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Cameco has a 31.6% interest in the Bruce Power Limited Partnership. Bruce Power&#146;s business is
	the generation and sale of electricity into the Ontario wholesale market. Bruce Power generates
	electricity from four Bruce B and two Bruce A nuclear-powered units. These six units have the
	capacity to supply about 20% of Ontario&#146;s electricity needs.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	In addition to the carrying value of its investment in Bruce Power, Cameco has provided certain
	financial assurances on behalf of the partnership. Cameco&#146;s maximum exposure under these
	arrangements is $203&nbsp;million. At December&nbsp;31, 2004, the actual exposure was $130&nbsp;million. See note
	16 to the consolidated financial statements.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Cameco has extended a $75&nbsp;million loan to the partnership. The loan is due February&nbsp;14, 2008 and
	bears interest at 10.5% per annum. At December&nbsp;31, 2004, the entire amount was outstanding.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Cameco has entered into fuel supply agreements with Bruce Power for the procurement of the
	fabricated fuel. Under these agreements, Cameco will supply uranium and conversion services, and
	contract for and finance the purchase of fabrication services. Contract terms are generally at
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	27
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage193"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
<A HREF="#O15894EXV3_HTM_TOCPAGE">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	market rates and on normal trade terms. During 2004, sales of uranium and conversion services to
	Bruce Power amounted to $25&nbsp;million, representing 2.4% of Cameco&#146;s total revenue. At December&nbsp;31,
	2004, amounts receivable under these agreements amounted to $21&nbsp;million.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Ontario Electricity Market
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	On December&nbsp;9, 2004, the Ontario government passed legislation that will restructure the
	electricity sector to address the widening gap between supply and demand in the province. Bill 100
	details a range of measures intended to encourage private investment, expand market participation,
	maintain price stability and construct or conserve 25,000 MW of capacity by 2020.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	The government has established the Ontario Power Authority to ensure adequate supply, and to
	promote new supply through requests for proposals or other negotiations.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	The bill includes a requirement that the Independent Electricity System Operator (previously the
	Independent Electricity Market Operator) ensures that power users pay the true cost of electricity,
	taking into consideration the mix of regulated and market prices paid to generators. Cameco expects
	the legislation will bring much needed clarity and stability to Ontario&#146;s electricity sector.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Nuclear Electricity Business &#151; Key Performance Drivers
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	The major factors that drive Bruce Power&#146;s results are:
<P>
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="1%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	prices,
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD COLSPAN="5">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="1%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	volume, and
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD COLSPAN="5">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="1%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	costs.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Prices
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Bruce Power earnings are significantly affected by fluctuations in electricity spot market prices,
	which in turn are affected by supply (temporary generating station shutdowns) and demand (mainly
	driven by weather).
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	To reduce its exposure to fluctuations in spot market prices, Bruce Power has a portfolio of
	fixed-price sales contracts. Bruce Power&#146;s proportion of output being sold under fixed price
	contracts will continue to decrease in 2005. For 2005, 36% of Bruce Power&#146;s planned output is
	expected to be sold under fixed-price contracts. This compares with 48% in 2004 and 65% in 2003.
	The major reason is the uncertainty in Ontario&#146;s electricity market, as buyers and sellers have
	adopted a &#147;wait and see&#148; attitude to forward contracting until the market structure is stronger.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Volume
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Bruce Power&#146;s output is affected by shutdowns, both those that are planned for maintenance and
	those that are unplanned. Bruce Power attempts to achieve high output through effective maintenance
	programs, as well as various investments that can help secure and improve performance. Since about
	95% of Bruce Power&#146;s costs are fixed, volume improvements are directly reflected in financial
	results.
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	28
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage194"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
<A HREF="#O15894EXV3_HTM_TOCPAGE">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Costs
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	In 2004, operating costs (including depreciation and amortization) totalled $1,178&nbsp;million, 38%
	higher than in 2003. This was due primarily to the fact that six units are operational rather than
	four and the resulting increase in staff and material costs.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Growth
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Bruce Units A1 &#038; A2
</B>
<BR>
<BR>
	Bruce Power is examining the feasibility of restarting Bruce A units 1 and 2 to serve Ontario&#146;s
	growing electricity needs. The feasibility study and project plan are expected to be completed in
	2005 and Bruce Power management and the Bruce Power partners will review them. Cameco expects to
	make a decision in 2005 on whether or not to proceed with this investment.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Cameco believes that looking at restarting these two units is a logical first step in determining
	if Bruce Power can play a growing role in meeting Ontario&#146;s future energy needs. The study will
	determine if an adequate return on investment can be achieved. The study will also establish what
	improvements are needed to extend the lives of the four Bruce B reactors and the two operating
	Bruce A reactors, which are scheduled to be taken out of service over the next 15&nbsp;years.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
<I>
	Point Lepreau
</I>
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Cameco, together with TransCanada and BPC Generation Infrastructure Trust, continues to study the
	potential investment in the Point Lepreau nuclear generating station in New Brunswick. They have
	asked Bruce Power Inc. to conduct on-site due diligence as part of an evaluation of the facility.
	The evaluation process and discussions continue, with New Brunswick Power asking Bruce Power to
	submit a firm proposal for the refurbishment of the Point Lepreau station.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Point Lepreau is a 680-MW Candu reactor similar to the Bruce Power reactors in Ontario.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Capability to Deliver Results
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Bruce Power has an experienced executive team leading about 3,600 highly skilled employees.
	Together they achieved a 37% increase in output during a year where a vacuum building inspection
	was completed and required the four B units to be shutdown for about one month. Bruce Power has
	invested, and continues to invest, substantial amounts to improve reactor output and reliability.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	At the same time, Bruce Power&#146;s ongoing emphasis on safety was reflected in its accident frequency
	of zero acute lost-time injuries for every 200,000 hours worked in 2004. That was significantly
	better than the company&#146;s already ambitious target of 0.2 acute lost-time injuries for every
	200,000 hours worked.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Bruce Power&#146;s cash flows provide a source of funds to make investments that improve its operational
	performance and expand its capacity.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Cameco has a goal to expand its nuclear generation business using Bruce Power and through Cameco
	directed activities. We can draw upon our direct experience from Cameco&#146;s partnership
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	29
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage195"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
<A HREF="#O15894EXV3_HTM_TOCPAGE">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	in Bruce Power and will further enhance our capabilities internally to pursue further growth in
	this business.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Cameco intends to build in-house expertise in reactor operations and electricity marketing. We seek
	to do this in a number of ways. First, when possible, we gain insight into the operational and
	commercial side of the business from Bruce Power. Second, we pursue nuclear generating
	opportunities that have the potential to augment our knowledge. For example, when Cameco bid on the
	South Texas Project, which we ultimately did not win, we would have had the opportunity to market
	our share of the electricity in the Texas market. The South Texas Project would have also given us
	more insight into light water reactor technology, expanding our knowledge beyond the Candu
	technology at Bruce Power. Third, we seek active ownership to allow, where possible, participation
	in management oversight of generation facilities.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Electricity Business Results
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	The operating results of Bruce Power are accounted for using the equity method and thus
	Cameco&#146;s share of Bruce Power earnings are not consolidated with Cameco&#146;s net earnings.

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P>
<HR SIZE="1" WIDTH="18%" ALIGN="LEFT" NOSHADE COLOR="#000000">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	*Capacity factor for a given period represents the amount of electricity actually produced for
	sale as a percentage of the amount of electricity the plants are capable of producing for sale.
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	30
</DIV>

<!-- END TABLE BODY -->
</TABLE>
</DIV>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Earnings
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	In 2004, Bruce Power earnings before taxes were $338&nbsp;million compared to $286&nbsp;million in 2003.
	The increase can be attributed to higher electricity generation in 2004 compared to 2003.
	Cameco&#146;s pre-tax earnings from Bruce Power in 2004 amounted to $121&nbsp;million compared to $108
	million in 2003.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Revenue
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	In 2004, revenue totalled $1,583&nbsp;million, up 31% from 2003. Bruce Power&#146;s realized price averaged
	$47 per MWh from a mix of contract and spot sales, a 2% decrease over the same period last year.
	The Ontario electricity spot price averaged about $50 per MWh during 2004 compared to $54 per MWh a
	year earlier. During 2004, about 48% of Bruce Power&#146;s output was sold under fixed-price contracts
	compared to 65% in 2003.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	The Bruce Power units achieved a total capacity factor of 82% in 2004, down from 85% in 2003.
	Bruce Power produced 33.6 TWh in 2004, an increase of 37% over the previous year, reflecting the
	addition of the two A units, as well as the 3% increase in reactor power at unit B6, which was
	achieved through fuel reconfiguration.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Costs
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	In 2004, operating costs (including depreciation and amortization) totalled $1,178&nbsp;million, 38%
	higher than in 2003. This was primarily as a result of operating six units rather than four and
	the resulting increase in staff and material costs.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Cash operating costs were impacted by outage expenses incurred during 2004 and included $16&nbsp;million
	for the technical feasibility study of restarting units A1 and A2. In 2004, depreciation and
	amortization expense was up 81% compared to 2003 due primarily to the amortization of capital costs
	related to the restart of units A3 and A4.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	About 95% of Bruce Power&#146;s operating costs are fixed. As such, most of the costs are incurred
	whether the plant is operating or not. On a per unit basis, the 2004 operating cost was $35 per
	MWh, similar to 2003.
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	31
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage197"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
<A HREF="#O15894EXV3_HTM_TOCPAGE">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Cash from Operations
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	For 2004, Bruce Power generated $439&nbsp;million in cash from operations compared to $387&nbsp;million in
	2003 due to increased generation. All of Bruce Power&#146;s cash flow has been reinvested in its
	plants.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Capital Expenditures
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	In 2004, capital expenditures were $359&nbsp;million compared to $528&nbsp;million in 2003 when programs to
	restart units A3 and A4 were under way. The $359&nbsp;million expenditure in 2004 was less than the
	expected $400&nbsp;million due to a reorganization of planned outages, some savings and a deferral of
	about $15&nbsp;million into 2005.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	For 2004, Bruce Power&#146;s operating cash flows, along with cash on hand, allowed for the
	repayment of $110&nbsp;million of short-term debt.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Outlook for 2005
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Bruce Power&#146;s results in 2005 are anticipated to decline modestly from 2004 due to increased
	costs related to higher depreciation and amortization on the A units, higher outage costs and
	higher fuel costs. Results, however, are sensitive to the Ontario electricity price, where the
	market structure is under review, and the operating performance of the Bruce Power units.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	2005 Planned Outages
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Refurbishment of existing unit critical components is planned in 2005 as part of the maintenance
	program outlined below. Capacity factors for the year are expected to average about 85%. For 2006,
	a significant reduction in time and expenditure on refurbishment programs for the six reactors
	currently operating is anticipated. This excludes any potential refurbishment efforts for units A1
	and A2. The long-term goal is to reach a capacity factor of 90%.

<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	2005 Capital Expenditures (100%)
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Bruce Power capital expenditure program for the two A and four B units is expected to total $375
	million in 2005. This includes $110&nbsp;million for sustaining capital and site service support, with
	the balance for refurbishment and upgrades.

	&nbsp;
</TD>

<!-- END TABLE BODY -->
</TABLE>
</DIV>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Cameco expects that funding of these projects will come entirely from Bruce Power cash flows.
	However, available funds will depend on the electricity market prices and the operational
	performance of the Bruce Power reactors.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	At this level of planned capital expenditures, and excluding any new capital expenditures for
	growth initiatives such as the restart of units A1 and A2, cash distributions from Bruce Power are
	possible in 2005. The partnership will determine whether to take cash distributions or reinvest in
	Bruce Power or other growth initiatives. Any cash distributions will depend on the Ontario
	electricity market prices and the operating performance of Bruce Power.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Electricity Price Sensitivity Analysis
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	For 2005, about 36% of Bruce Power&#146;s planned output will be under fixed-price contracts. A $1.00
	per MWh change in the spot price for electricity in Ontario would change Cameco&#146;s after-tax
	earnings from Bruce Power by about $5&nbsp;million.
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT">
<A NAME="O15894EXV3_HTM_108">
</A>
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
<I>
	GOLD
</I>
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Centerra Gold Inc.
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Cameco owns 52.7% of Centerra, which is listed and publicly traded on the Toronto Stock
	Exchange (TSX). Centerra began trading on the TSX under the symbol CG in June&nbsp;2004. We transferred
	substantially all of our gold assets to Centerra as part of our strategy to unlock the value
	contained in these gold properties.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	The geographic focus of Centerra&#146;s exploration, development, and acquisition efforts is in Central
	Asia and the former Soviet Union. Centerra is a leading North American gold producer and the
	largest western-based gold producer in Central Asia and the former Soviet Union.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Centerra owns 100% of the Kumtor mine in the Kyrgyz Republic, a 95% interest in the Boroo mine in
	Mongolia and operates both mines. It also has interests in exploration properties, including a 100%
	interest in the Gatsuurt property in Mongolia, 35 kilometres from the Boroo mine, and a 62%
	interest in the REN property in Nevada.
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	33
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage199"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
<A HREF="#O15894EXV3_HTM_TOCPAGE">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Centerra&#146;s growth strategy is to increase its reserve base and expand its current portfolio of gold
	mining operations by:
<P>
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="3%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	developing new reserves at existing mines from in-pit, adjacent and regional
	exploration,
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD COLSPAN="5">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="3%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	further delineating the mineralized zone at the REN property on the Carlin Trend in
	Nevada,
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD COLSPAN="5">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="3%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	pursuing new gold properties through exploration programs focused primarily on Central
	Asia and the former Soviet Union and other emerging markets, and
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD COLSPAN="5">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="3%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	actively pursuing selective acquisitions, with a focus on mid-to advanced-stage
	exploration and development properties primarily in Central Asia, the former Soviet Union
	and other emerging markets.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	At the end of 2004, Centerra announced it had:
<P>
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="3%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	increased reserves at both of its mines, extending mine lives by about one year, and
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD COLSPAN="5">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="3%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	significantly expanded resources at the Gatsuurt and REN projects.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Centerra is building its exploration program to further expand its reserve base and is actively
	seeking acquisitions. Cameco believes that Centerra will be successful in its growth strategy and
	ultimately add more value to our investment in Centerra.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	In the longer term, Cameco will look for the right opportunity to reduce its gold investment and
	ultimately fully divest. It is not our intention to sell quickly, but rather to encourage Centerra
	to grow and gain value for Cameco&#146;s shareholders. The decision whether to divest will also depend
	on the need to fund other investment opportunities in the nuclear energy business.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	For further information on Centerra, please see its annual report and annual information form for
	2004 published in 2005.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Gold Operating Results
</B>
<BR>
<BR>
	The operating results of the Kumtor Gold Company (Kumtor) have been fully consolidated as of
	June&nbsp;22, 2004. Prior to that, Cameco proportionately consolidated its interest in Kumtor. Cameco
	also fully consolidates the results of Boroo, Centerra&#146;s gold mine in Mongolia. Cameco adjusts for
	a 47% minority interest in Centerra, which reflects that share of earnings attributable to
	shareholders other than Cameco.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	(Fully consolidated financial highlights including the minority interest)

<P>
<HR SIZE="1" WIDTH="18%" ALIGN="LEFT" NOSHADE COLOR="#000000">
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="1%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
<SUP STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 85%; VERTICAL-ALIGN: TEXT-TOP">
	1
</SUP>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="96%">
	Beginning
	in the third quarter of 2004, Cameco fully consolidates Kumtor&#146;s
	results.
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="3%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="1%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
<SUP STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 85%; VERTICAL-ALIGN: TEXT-TOP">
	2
</SUP>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="96%">
	Total cash cost is a non-GAAP measure and is discussed under &#147;Non-GAAP measures &#151; Total
	cash costs&#148;
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="3%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="1%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
<SUP STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 85%; VERTICAL-ALIGN: TEXT-TOP">
	3
</SUP>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="96%">
	Commercial operations commenced March&nbsp;1, 2004.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Gold Financial Results
</B>
<BR>
<BR>
	In 2004, revenue from the gold business increased to $323&nbsp;million from $114&nbsp;million in 2003,
	reflecting the full consolidation of Kumtor&#146;s results since June&nbsp;2004 as well as production from
	the Boroo mine. A higher realized price for gold also added to revenue, increasing to $397 (US)&nbsp;in
	2004 compared to $334 (US)&nbsp;in 2003. This was due to a reduced hedge level, which provided greater
	exposure to the higher spot price. The Canadian dollar revenue does not reflect this entire
	increase due to the strength of the Canadian dollar relative to 2003.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Production at the Kumtor mine decreased by 20,224 ounces in 2004 due to a lower ore grade that
	averaged 4.4 g/t compared to 4.5 g/t in 2003. Kumtor&#146;s total cash cost per ounce increased slightly
	to $202 (US)&nbsp;compared to $191 (US)&nbsp;in 2003 due to the decrease in production.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Production at Boroo totalled 217,998 ounces since commercial production was declared on March&nbsp;1,
	2004. Boroo&#146;s total cash cost per ounce was $149 (US)&nbsp;for the 10-month post-commercialization
	period.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	The gross profit margin for gold declined marginally to 34% in 2004 compared to 35% in 2003.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Gold Outlook for 2005
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Based on Centerra&#146;s current operations, total production for the year is forecast at 762,000
	ounces, a decline of almost 16% from 2004, primarily as a result of lower ore grades at the
	Kumtor mine. However, Centerra&#146;s share of production is expected to increase to 750,000 ounces
	from 610,287 in 2004 due to the increased ownership level in both mines and a full year of
	operation at Boroo.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	At Kumtor, production in 2005 is expected to decline to 512,000 ounces from 657,329 ounces in
	2004, due to a lower ore grade averaging 3.5 grams per tonne (g/t) compared to 4.4 g/t in 2004.
	Total cash costs at Kumtor are expected to be higher at $255 (US)&nbsp;per ounce due to the reduced
	production. As a result, profits are expected to be lower than in 2004. For Boroo, 2005
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	35
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage201"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
<A HREF="#O15894EXV3_HTM_TOCPAGE">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	production is expected to be similar to 2004, at about 250,000 ounces. Total cash cost is
	forecast to be $179 (US)&nbsp;per ounce.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Overall, gold earnings are expected to decline in 2005 from 2004 due to higher costs as a
	result of lower grades at Kumtor.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	In January&nbsp;2005, Centerra announced new reserve and resources estimates for its properties.
	Based on these estimates, Centerra has reported that the mine life at both Kumtor and Boroo
	would be extended by one year. Cameco&#146;s annual information form
	for 2004 includes these new reserve and resource estimates.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Gold Price Sensitivity Analysis
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	For 2005, gold sales are unhedged. A $10.00 (US)&nbsp;per ounce change in the gold spot price would
	change Cameco revenue by about $10&nbsp;million (Cdn), cash flow by about $9&nbsp;million (Cdn) and net
	earnings by about $4&nbsp;million (Cdn).
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT">
<A NAME="O15894EXV3_HTM_109">
</A>
</DIV>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_98"></A>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
<I>
	2004 FOURTH QUARTER CONSOLIDATED RESULTS
</I>
</B>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER">
<TABLE STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT" CELLSPACING="0" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<!-- BEGIN TABLE HEAD -->
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD WIDTH="65%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>

</DIV>
<P>
<HR SIZE="1" WIDTH="18%" ALIGN="LEFT" NOSHADE COLOR="#000000">
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="1%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	(a)
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="98%">
	All per share amounts reflect the share split on December&nbsp;31, 2004.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Consolidated revenue rose 33% to $361&nbsp;million in the fourth quarter of 2004, while net
	earnings increased 9% to $37&nbsp;million or $0.21 per share. The improvement in fourth quarter net
	earnings was primarily due to higher realized prices in the uranium and gold businesses as well as
	significantly higher gold production.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	These improvements were partially offset by reduced earnings in the conversion business and higher
	charges for administration, exploration and interest. Administration costs increased by $5&nbsp;million
	due to higher expenses associated with operating Centerra Gold Inc. as a separate publicly traded
	company and increased stock compensation expenses.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Exploration expenses rose by $7&nbsp;million reflecting the increased activity in the uranium and gold
	businesses. Interest and other costs were up $3&nbsp;million as they included $7&nbsp;million in deferred
	issue costs related to the redemption of Cameco&#146;s 8.75% preferred securities in the quarter. The
	impact of this expense was partially offset by higher interest income earned on cash balances
	held by Centerra.
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	36
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage202"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
<A HREF="#O15894EXV3_HTM_TOCPAGE">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	The effective tax rate decreased to 10% in the fourth quarter of 2004, compared to 41% in the
	same period of 2003 due to a higher proportion of earnings coming from lower tax jurisdictions. The
	tax rate for the fourth quarter of 2003 reflected the impact of a change in Ontario tax
	legislation. Excluding the tax adjustment, the effective rate in the fourth quarter of 2003 was
	32%.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Cash provided by operations in the fourth quarter was $59&nbsp;million, compared to $79&nbsp;million in the
	same period a year ago due to increased working capital requirements during the quarter.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	For more information on the fourth quarter of 2004, please see Cameco news release dated January
	27, 2004.
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT">
<A NAME="O15894EXV3_HTM_110">

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="1%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	(a)
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="96%">
	Per share amount reflects the share split on December&nbsp;31, 2004.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	The following points are intended to assist the reader in analysing the trends in the
	quarterly financial highlights for 2004.
<P>
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="3%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	Revenue trended higher throughout the four quarters due largely to a change in the
	ownership interest in the Kumtor mine. The third and fourth quarter revenues reflect the
	full consolidation of operating results from Kumtor whereas they were proportionately
	consolidated in the first half of the year.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD COLSPAN="5">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="3%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	Revenue was significantly lower in the first quarter due to lower deliveries of uranium
	and conversion services.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD COLSPAN="5">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="3%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	Net earnings do not trend with revenue and varied significantly from quarter to quarter
	for two main reasons. First, Cameco&#146;s earnings are significantly influenced by results from
	Bruce Power. The equity method of accounting is applied to the investment in Bruce Power
	and therefore no revenue is recorded. Second, the net earnings in the second quarter of
	2004 reflect a net gain of $89&nbsp;million as a result of the Centerra restructuring
	transactions which occurred in June.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT">
<A NAME="O15894EXV3_HTM_111">
</A>
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
<I>
	2004 CONSOLIDATED RESULTS
</I>
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Consolidated Earnings
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	For 2004, Cameco&#146;s net earnings were $279&nbsp;million ($1.63 per share) compared to $208&nbsp;million
	($1.24 per share) in 2003. The earnings for each of these years include unusual items, which make
	comparisons difficult. In 2004, Cameco recorded a net gain of $94&nbsp;million related to the
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	37
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage203"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
<A HREF="#O15894EXV3_HTM_TOCPAGE">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Centerra
	restructuring transactions and the results for 2003 included an $81&nbsp;million tax adjustment as a
	result of changes in Canadian federal and Ontario provincial tax legislation.
	Excluding these items, Cameco recorded adjusted net earnings of $185&nbsp;million ($1.08 per share)
	compared to $127&nbsp;million ($0.75 per share) recorded in 2003. This $58&nbsp;million increase was
	attributable to improved results in the uranium and gold businesses as well as stronger
	performance at Bruce Power, partially offset by higher charges for administration and
	exploration.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	The improvement in the uranium business was due to a higher realized price, which was related
	mainly to the significant increase in the spot price for uranium. Earnings from Bruce Power
	benefited from a 37% increase in generation as a result of the restart of two A reactors (units 3
	and 4). Results from the gold business improved due to increased production and a higher realized
	selling price.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Excluding the tax adjustment in 2003, the effective rate for income taxes in 2004 decreased to
	19% from 33% as a higher proportion of earnings came from lower tax jurisdictions. Earnings from
	operations were $125&nbsp;million compared to $75&nbsp;million in 2003 and the aggregate gross profit
	margin increased to 23% from 20% in 2003.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Corporate Expenses
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Administration
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	In 2004, administration costs were $70&nbsp;million, an increase of $22&nbsp;million due to a combination
	of higher costs related to establishing and operating Centerra ($9&nbsp;million), increased stock
	compensation expenses ($5&nbsp;million) and higher expenditures for regulatory compliance. In 2004,
	Cameco and its subsidiaries incurred costs of $2&nbsp;million related to Sarbanes-Oxley compliance. In
	addition, there were increased costs associated with growth and quality initiatives.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Effective January&nbsp;1, 2003, Cameco changed its accounting policy for stock-based compensation opting
	to record compensation expense at the fair value of the options granted. The total expense is
	amortized over the vesting period of the options. For 2004, stock option expenses amounted to $7.2
	million compared to $2.4&nbsp;million in 2003. See note 17 of the consolidated financial statements.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Interest and other
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	In 2004, interest and other costs declined by $2&nbsp;million compared to 2003 due to reduced foreign
	exchange losses ($3&nbsp;million) and to gains related to the ineffective portion of derivative hedging
	instruments ($7&nbsp;million). These improvements were partially offset by expenses recorded in
	connection with the redemption of the 8.75% preferred securities in 2004. As a result of the
	redemption, Cameco expensed $7&nbsp;million in deferred issue costs, which were previously being
	amortized over the 49-year life of the preferred securities. See note 11 of the consolidated
	financial statements.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Income Taxes
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	In 2004, income tax expense amounted to $73&nbsp;million compared to a net recovery of $21&nbsp;million for
	2003. The tax expense for 2003 included $81&nbsp;million in recoveries as a result of changes in
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	38
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage204"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
<A HREF="#O15894EXV3_HTM_TOCPAGE">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Canadian federal and Ontario provincial tax legislation.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Excluding the effects of the changes in legislation, income tax expense for 2004 was $13&nbsp;million
	greater than in 2003. The effective income tax rate declined to 19% from 33% as a higher proportion
	of earnings came from lower tax jurisdictions.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Income tax expense also includes large corporations taxes which amounted to $6&nbsp;million in 2004 and
	$5&nbsp;million in 2003. See note 13 of the consolidated financial statements.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Cash Resources
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Operating Activities
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	In 2004, Cameco generated cash from operations of $228&nbsp;million compared to $250&nbsp;million in 2003.
	This decrease of $22&nbsp;million was primarily due to an increase in inventory levels, which more than
	offset the benefit of higher revenue.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Cameco&#146;s cash from operations does not include its pro rata interest in Bruce Power&#146;s operating
	cash flow. The pro rata share was $139&nbsp;million in 2004 compared to $117&nbsp;million in 2003. Cameco
	accounts for this investment using the equity method and thus Bruce Power&#146;s operating cash flows
	are not consolidated with Cameco&#146;s. For further information, refer to note 16 (c)&nbsp;of the
	consolidated financial statements.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Investing Activities
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Cash used in investing activities decreased to $161&nbsp;million from $463&nbsp;million in 2003. This
	decline of $302&nbsp;million was largely attributable to the $279&nbsp;million investment in Bruce Power in
	2003. In addition, expenditures in 2003 reflected the development of the Boroo mine. For 2004,
	investing activities included $34&nbsp;million for sustaining capital at McArthur River/Key Lake, $28
	million in development costs at Cigar Lake and $25&nbsp;million in capitalized interest charges. The
	restructuring of the gold business required a net cash outlay of $4&nbsp;million.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Financing Activities
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	In 2004, cash provided by operations exceeded cash used in investing activities by $67&nbsp;million,
	allowing the company to repay $54&nbsp;million of its long-term debt during the year. The initial public offering of common
	shares in Centerra generated $101&nbsp;million after underwriters&#146; fees. See note 20(a) of the
	consolidated financial statements.
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	39
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage205"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
<A HREF="#O15894EXV3_HTM_TOCPAGE">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Balance Sheet
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Cash
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	At December&nbsp;31, 2004, the consolidated cash balance totalled $190&nbsp;million and Centerra held
	substantially the entire amount.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Inventories
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	At the end of 2004, total product inventories amounted to $387&nbsp;million, $71&nbsp;million or 22% higher
	than the previous year end. Of this increase, about $30&nbsp;million was related to higher uranium
	inventory levels and about $25&nbsp;million was due to an increase in unit costs for uranium. The
	remainder was related to higher gold inventory levels. See note 3 to the consolidated financial
	statements.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Debt
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Effective January&nbsp;1, 2004, Cameco changed its accounting policy for financial instruments. This
	change resulted in the preferred securities and convertible debentures being classified as debt
	rather than equity. See note 2(b) to the consolidated financial statements.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	On December&nbsp;17, 2004, Cameco redeemed its 8.75% preferred securities, due September&nbsp;30, 2047, in
	the principal amount of $125&nbsp;million (US). The redemption of the principal amount plus accrued and
	unpaid interest was funded with lower-cost commercial paper.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	At December&nbsp;31, 2004, total long-term debt was $519&nbsp;million, a decrease of $87&nbsp;million
	compared to December&nbsp;31, 2003. At December&nbsp;31, 2004, Cameco&#146;s consolidated net debt to
	capitalization ratio was 13%, down from 22% at the end of 2003.
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>

<P>
<A NAME="eolPage206"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">

	Table of Contents

</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Off-Balance Sheet Arrangements
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	In the normal course of operations, Cameco enters into certain transactions which are not required
	to be recorded on its balance sheet. These activities include the issuing of financial assurances,
	derivative instruments and long-term product purchase contracts. These arrangements are discussed
	in the following sections of this MD&#038;A and the notes to the financial statements:
<P>
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="3%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	1.&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
<B>
	Financial assurances
</B>
	&#150; disclosed in
<U>
	Nuclear Electricity Business
</U>
	on page 26,
<U>
	Liquidity and Capital Resources
</U>
	on page 42,
<U>
	Business Risks and
	Uncertainties
</U>
	on page 50 and in notes 6, 7 and 16 of the consolidated financial
	statements.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD COLSPAN="5">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="3%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	2.&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
<B>
	Derivative instruments
</B>
	&#150; disclosed in
<U>
	Uranium Business
</U>
	on pages 16-17,
<U>
	Business Risks and Uncertainties
</U>
	on pages 46-47,
<U>
	Critical Accounting
	Estimates
</U>
	on page 52 and in note 22 of the consolidated financial statements.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD COLSPAN="5">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="3%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	3.&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
<B>
	Long-term product purchase contracts
</B>
	&#150; disclosed in
<U>
	Uranium Business
</U>
	on page
	15,
<U>
	Liquidity and Capital Resources
</U>
	on page 42 and in note 21(d) of the
	consolidated financial statements.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT">
<A NAME="O15894EXV3_HTM_112">
</A>
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
<I>
	CONSOLIDATED OUTLOOK FOR 2005
</I>
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	In 2005, consolidated revenue is expected to grow by about 10% over 2004 due to increases in
	the uranium and gold businesses. On a consolidated basis, the gross profit margin is projected to
	improve from the 23% reported in 2004.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	In the uranium business, revenue is likely to be significantly higher due to a stronger realized
	price and increased volumes. Revenue from the conversion business is likely to be marginally
	higher than in 2004 due to an expected 5% increase in the average realized selling price, largely
	offset by lower deliveries.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Bruce Power results in 2005 are anticipated to decline modestly from 2004 due to increased costs
	related to higher depreciation and amortization on the A units, higher outage costs and higher fuel
	costs.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Revenue in the gold business is expected to be higher due primarily to a full year of
	consolidating the results from Kumtor, a wholly owned subsidiary of Centerra. However, gold
	results are anticipated to decline in 2005 from 2004 due to higher costs as a result of expected
	lower grades at Kumtor.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	In 2005, total capital expenditures are expected to more than double to $300&nbsp;million. Capital
	expenditures are classified as growth or sustaining. Growth capital is defined to be capital
	spent to bring on incremental production. Everything else is sustaining capital. Cameco expects
	it will have sufficient debt capacity and cash from operations to fund our capital expenditure
	program.
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	41
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage207"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
<A HREF="#O15894EXV3_HTM_TOCPAGE">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	For growth projects, total
	expenditures are projected to be $167&nbsp;million, an increase of $118
	million compared to 2004. The increase is attributable to:
<P>
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="4%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	development activity at Cigar Lake and Inkai,
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD COLSPAN="5">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="4%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	construction of the slightly enriched uranium (SEU)&nbsp;blending facility at Port Hope, and
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD COLSPAN="5">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="4%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	expansion of production capacity at McArthur River and US ISL mines.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER">
<TABLE STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT" CELLSPACING="0" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<!-- BEGIN TABLE HEAD -->
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD WIDTH="100%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<!-- END TABLE HEAD -->
<!-- BEGIN TABLE BODY -->
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:15PX; TEXT-INDENT:-15PX">
	Expansion at McArthur River, producing SEU at Port Hope and development at Inkai are subject to
	regulatory approvals.
</DIV>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD>
	Sustaining capital expenditures are expected to be higher in 2005 than in 2004 due to ongoing mine
	development work, pumping and water treatment projects at McArthur River, and well field expansions
	at the US ISL operations. Sustaining capital expenditures will also increase at conversion services
	to improve production processes and meet new regulatory requirements.
</TD>
</TR>
<!-- END TABLE BODY -->
</TABLE>
</DIV>

<DIV ALIGN="LEFT">
<A NAME="O15894EXV3_HTM_113">

</DIV>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
<I>
	LIQUIDITY AND CAPITAL RESOURCES
</I>
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Overview
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Financial liquidity represents the company&#146;s ability to fund future operating activities and
	investments. Some important measures of liquidity are summarized in the table below.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	In 2004, Cameco redeemed all $125&nbsp;million (US)&nbsp;of its outstanding 8.75% preferred securities.
	Cameco also replaced its revolving credit facility with a new $500&nbsp;million, five-year, unsecured
	revolving credit facility.
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	42
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->

	Indicators Defined

	consideration for changes in working capital.

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P>
<HR NOSHADE SIZE="1" WIDTH="18%" ALIGN="LEFT" COLOR="#000000">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	1&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Total debt less cash and cash equivalents. Based on consolidated amounts.
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Cash provided by operations to net debt indicates the company&#146;s ability to meet debt
	obligations from internally generated funds. Cash provided by operations does not include Cameco&#146;s
	pro rata interest in Bruce Power&#146;s operating cash flow of $139&nbsp;million in 2004 compared to $117
	million in 2003. Cameco accounts for this investment using the equity method and thus Bruce Power&#146;s
	operating cash flows are not consolidated with Cameco&#146;s. For further information, refer to note
	16(c) of the consolidated financial statements.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Net debt to total capitalization measures the company&#146;s use of financial leverage. A lower
	percentage means less reliance upon debt as a source of financing. Although debt is a lower cost
	form of financing compared to equity, a lower percentage of debt also represents lower repayment
	obligations. At December&nbsp;31, 2004, the consolidated cash balance totalled $190&nbsp;million and Centerra
	held substantially the entire amount for its own use.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Credit Ratings
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	As of February&nbsp;2005, the company has the following ratings for its senior debt from
	third-party rating agencies:
<P>
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="4%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	Dominion Bond Rating Service Limited
<BR>
	&#147;A (low)&#148; with a stable outlook.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD COLSPAN="5">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="4%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	Moody&#146;s Investors Service
<BR>
	&#147;Baa1&#148; with a stable outlook.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD COLSPAN="5">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="4%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	Standard &#038; Poor&#146;s
<BR>
	&#147;BBB&#043;&#148; with a stable outlook.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
	Debt
</B>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	In addition to cash flow from operations, debt is used to provide liquidity. Cameco has access
	to about $740&nbsp;million in unsecured lines of credit.
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Commercial lenders have provided a $500&nbsp;million five-year, unsecured, revolving credit facility,
	available until November&nbsp;30, 2009, with annual extension provisions. Up to $100&nbsp;million of this
	facility can be used to support letters of credit. The facility ranks equally with all other senior
	debt of the company. At December&nbsp;31, 2004, there were no amounts outstanding under these credit
	facilities.
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	43
</DIV>
